text: This is the LORD'S doing; it is marvellous in our eyes.
text_kjv: This is the LORD'S doing; it is marvellous in our eyes.
text_niv: the Lord has done this,and it is marvelous in our eyes.
text_esv: This is the LORD's doing; it is marvelous in our eyes.
text_nlt: This is the LORD’s doing,and it is wonderful to see.
text_msg: This is God's work.We rub our eyes—we can hardly believe it!
text_nasb: This is the LORD'S doing; It is marvelous in our eyes.
context: Psalm 118 is a hymn of thanksgiving, likely used during the Feast of Tabernacles or Passover, important festivals celebrating God's deliverance of Israel. Its structure involves a call to worship, a recounting of God's steadfast love (hesed), and a triumphant procession into the temple. This particular verse, Psalm 118:23, forms the climax of the psalm, following the declaration that the rejected stone has become the cornerstone (v. 22). The 'stone' metaphor likely referred to Israel itself, initially considered insignificant or inadequate by other nations, or perhaps to a specific leader or group within Israel who were initially dismissed but ultimately proved essential for the nation's salvation. The historical context could also reference David, initially a shepherd boy deemed unfit to be king, or even the Maccabees, who led a rebellion against foreign rule after being marginalized. The celebratory tone indicates a moment of profound relief and gratitude after a period of struggle or perceived weakness. Temple worship in this era was highly ritualized, involving sacrifices, music, and responsive readings. Understanding the liturgical context enriches our interpretation; the psalm wasn't simply read, it was enacted and experienced corporately, amplifying the emotional impact of each verse. The use of the divine name 'LORD' (YHWH) emphasizes the personal and covenantal relationship between God and Israel, highlighting the faithfulness and power demonstrated in their deliverance.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 118:23 asserts God's sovereignty and ultimate control over events. The phrase 'This is the LORD's doing' emphasizes that the seemingly miraculous transformation – the rejected stone becoming the cornerstone – is not due to human ingenuity or luck, but solely the work of God. This underscores the concept of divine intervention and the belief that God actively participates in human history. It directly challenges any notion that success or deliverance is solely attributable to human effort. The 'marvellous in our eyes' declaration conveys a sense of awe and wonder, highlighting the profound impact of God's actions on the human perception of reality. The word 'marvellous' (niphlah in Hebrew) carries connotations of being extraordinary, surprising, and defying natural expectations. This verse resonates with the theme of God using the weak and foolish things of the world to shame the strong and wise (1 Corinthians 1:27). It is a testament to God's power to overturn seemingly insurmountable obstacles and bring about unexpected victories. It also points forward to the New Testament and the ultimate 'rejected stone,' Jesus Christ, who was crucified but resurrected and became the foundation of the Church. The psalm, therefore, speaks to the enduring hope that God can bring good out of even the most tragic and hopeless situations. This verse is a powerful affirmation of God's providential care and his ability to accomplish his purposes in ways that surpass human understanding.
application: In modern life, Psalm 118:23 serves as a potent reminder to recognize God's hand in our lives, particularly in situations where we experience unexpected breakthroughs or reversals of fortune. When facing setbacks, disappointments, or feelings of inadequacy, this verse encourages us to shift our perspective and look for God's active involvement. It prompts us to acknowledge that even the most challenging circumstances can be opportunities for God to display his power and grace. Consider situations where you've felt overlooked, underestimated, or rejected. Maybe you faced job rejections, relationship difficulties, or personal failures. Remember the 'rejected stone' metaphor. It urges us to trust that God can use these experiences to shape us, refine us, and ultimately position us for his purposes. Practically, this means cultivating a habit of gratitude and actively seeking God's presence in our daily lives. It involves praying for discernment to recognize his guiding hand, even when things don't make sense. It also means being open to unexpected opportunities and being willing to step outside of our comfort zones when God calls us to do so. Sharing testimonies of God's faithfulness with others can also strengthen our faith and encourage others to trust in his power. We can also apply this verse to our understanding of societal issues. When we witness injustice, inequality, or suffering, we can remember that God is still at work, even when it seems like darkness is prevailing. We can actively participate in seeking justice and working towards a more equitable world, trusting that God can use our efforts to bring about positive change. This verse is a call to active faith and unwavering hope, knowing that God is capable of transforming the seemingly impossible into the marvellously real.
prayer: Lord, thank you for your unwavering presence in my life. Forgive me for the times I've doubted your power and doubted your ability to work in my circumstances. Help me to see your hand in every situation, even when I don't understand. Give me eyes to recognize the 'marvellous' things you are doing around me. Strengthen my faith and deepen my trust in your perfect plan. Remind me that even when I feel rejected or overlooked, you are shaping me for a greater purpose. Fill me with a spirit of gratitude and a desire to share your goodness with others. I ask for your guidance as I navigate the challenges and uncertainties of life, trusting that you will lead me on the right path. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: This verse finds significant resonance in the New Testament, particularly with the imagery of Jesus as the rejected stone who becomes the cornerstone (Matthew 21:42; 1 Peter 2:7). Jesus, initially rejected by religious leaders, was ultimately exalted through his resurrection and became the foundation of the Church.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse: How does this verse relate to the New Testament?

faqs.answer: 'Marvellous in our eyes' signifies a profound sense of awe, wonder, and astonishment. It goes beyond simple appreciation; it describes a reaction to something so extraordinary that it defies expectations and evokes a sense of the divine. It highlights the unexpected and transformative nature of God's actions.
faqs.question: Q2: What does 'marvellous in our eyes' really mean?

faqs.answer: Absolutely. This verse serves as a powerful reminder that even in the midst of personal struggles, God is still at work. It encourages us to shift our perspective and look for his hand in our circumstances, trusting that he can bring about unexpected breakthroughs and victories. It fosters hope and resilience.
faqs.question: Q3: Can this verse be used in times of personal struggle?

faqs.answer: The emphasis on 'This is the LORD's doing' directly challenges human pride by highlighting that success and transformation are not solely attributable to human effort or ingenuity. It reminds us to acknowledge God's role in our achievements and to remain humble in the face of success.
faqs.question: Q4: How does this verse challenge human pride?

faqs.answer: Yes, this verse can be applied to organizations. When a company or team faces a seemingly insurmountable challenge and overcomes it, this verse serves as a reminder to acknowledge God's hand in their success and to foster a culture of gratitude and humility.
